reference.title: xxW_SDC-Modbus

ph.ph: The system output voltage (average/fast) is out of tolerance. The system might transfer to bypass if the bypass mains is within tolerance, if not the system turns off.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC warning level.

entry.ph: The system is in battery operation.
The system is in static bypass operation. Can be because the system switched to static bypass, a user changed to bypass from the display or the system is in hot standby.

ph.ph: The DC voltage is below the low V DC shutdown level. The supply to the inverter is too low and the inverter turns off. The system transfers to bypass if the bypass mains is within tolerance, if not the system turns off.
The DC output voltage after the serial diode is below DC warning level.

The DC voltage is above the high V DC shutdown level. The output of the rectifier is too high, and the rectifier turns off. The system transfers to battery operation if possible. Else the system transfers to bypass if the bypass mains is within tolerance, if not the system turns off.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC shutdown level. The DC input supply is too high. The system transfers to bypass if the bypass mains is within tolerance, if not the system turns off.
The DC output voltage after the serial diode is above the high DC warning/shutdown level.

entry.ph: The common alarm is active in the system.

The load on the inverter output has reached more than 100% of the nominal value. The system is overloaded. After some time, the system transfers to bypass if the bypass mains is within tolerance, if not the system turns off.

The temperature of one or both of the static switch modules (EA, EN) is above the shutdown level (> 100°C). The system transfers to an operating mode that does not use the overheated static switch if possible, or the system turns off.
The inverter is currently not in operation. The system can for example be in standby, bypass operation or the inverter is turned off. Does not trigger the common alarm.
The inverter is not synchronized to the bypass.
The battery current limiter is active, and has been active for more than 5 seconds. Does not trigger the common alarm.
Either the advanced battery monitor (ABM) test or the battery capacity test is running.
The battery temperature is too high or out of range, or the battery temperature sensor is inoperable or disconnected.
The DC voltage is below the low V DC warning level. If the DC voltage continues to decrease the alarm "Low DC shutdown" will activate.
The current is above the calibrated load profile (>150%) or the overcurrent protection is active on at least one of the inverter modules. The inverter is overloaded.

The bypass input voltage (average/fast) is out of tolerance. The system cannot switch to bypass operation. If the system is in bypass operation, and if the other supplies are unavailable, the system turns off.
Status of the first digital input connected to the NMC universal I/O sensor port (1 = Open, 0 = Closed).
Status of the second digital input connected to the NMC universal I/O sensor port (1 = Open, 0 = Closed).

ph.ph: The inverter fuse has blown. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or the system turns off.
Phase order not correct, or mains voltage is out of tolerance window, or mains is out of frequency window, or at least one phase is missing. Charger will shut down.
One or more of the following: One or more breakers are open, internal supply unavailable, no parallel communication, DC earth fault (Option 1), Option 2..6.
Rectifier mains input breaker is open.
At least one of the fans is rotating too slowly or is inoperable.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC warning level. If the DC voltage continues to increase the alarm "High DC shutdown" will activate.
The DC voltage is outside the set DC warning levels.
The inverter voltage is 15% below the internal reference. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or the system turns off.
The rectifier fuse (or fuses) has blown.

entry.ph: The current limiter for the total DC current is active for more than 5 seconds.
Load sharing differs more than ±10% for more than 30 seconds (only in redundant systems).

ph.ph: A internal power supply (AC or DC) not working
At least one of the standard redundant power supply units (AC or DC) are not working.
The battery monitor test shows that the battery capacity is below the defined defect level. Only available if optional Reality battery ABM is installed in the system.

entry.ph: Detected DC positive or negative earth leakage.
The DC or AC circuit of the redundant PSU is not working.

ph.ph: The rectifier transformer or choke temperature is too high. After 10 minutes the rectifier turns off and the system switches to battery or bypass operation if possible, or the system turns off.
The charger magnetics (charger, transformer, choke or diode) temperature is too high. The charger might switch off.
The battery temperature is too high. Only available if optional battery temperature sensor is installed at the battery.
The battery monitor test shows that the battery capacity is below the define warning level. Only available if optional Reality battery ABM is installed in the system.
The battery monitor test shows that the battery capacity is below the defined defect level. Only available if optional Reality battery ABM is installed in the system.
Option 1 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.
The system is locked in bypass operation, because the inverter has changed more than 8 times to bypass and back in two minutes.
Option 2 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.

entry.ph: Option 3 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.

ph.ph: Successful login to the level 2 (configuration stack). Does not trigger the common alarm.
Option 4 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.

The temperature of one or more inverter power modules (PM block1-4 L1-3) is above the shutdown level (> 100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or the system turns off.
Option 5 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.
The charger (0°/30°) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
Option 6 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.
The charger (0°/30°) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The rectifier turns off and the system switches to battery or bypass operation if possible, or the system turns off.
Option 7 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.
The system output voltage is above the tolerance level.
Option 8 input is open and the alarm signal is active. See the drawings for signal information if the option is used.
The temperature in one of the static switch modules (EA or EN) is above 90 °C (194 °F).
Half the battery voltage is outside the window of ±1.5%. A battery cell is defective. Only available if optional Reality battery ABM is installed in the system.
The current limiter for the total DC current is active for more than 5 seconds.

entry.ph: The AC capacitors current is below the warning level.
Output of system1 and system2 is not connected, or one of the systems is in standby or disconnected from power supply (only in redundant systems).
The AC capacitors current is below the shutdown level. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or the system turns off.
The rectifier mains voltage (average) is out of tolerance, or the rectifier mains frequency is out of tolerance.
The temperature is too high in one of the system charger modules.
1-phase systems: L1 to N,3-phase systems: L1 to L2.
L2 to L3. Only for 3-phase systems.
L3 to L1. Only for 3-phase systems.
1-phase systems: L1 to N, 3-phase systems: L1 to L2.
L2 to L3. Only for 3-phase systems.
L3 to L1. Only for 3-phase systems.
Value reflects the actual operation mode of the system:
The measured output voltage after the diode.

The measured battery temperature by the optional battery temperature sensor connected to the system. Unit of measure (Fahrenheit or Celsius) depends on a firmware setting. If the battery temperature sensor is not connected a very high value will be shown.
Percentage of the output power capacity used.
The calculated battery backup time left in minutes. Only available if optional Reality battery ABM is installed in the system.
The AOS firmware version for the network management card (NMC).
The APP firmware version for the network management card (NMC).
